column1: #Text=Release and pardon of killer jeopardises Armenia-Azerbaijan ceasefire
#Text=Image : Nicholas Babaian , Oleg Litvin , Jalpeyrie , Marshall Bagramyan .
#Text=Following Hungary 's release and repatriation of convicted Azeri axe-murderer Ramil Safarov , who Azerbaijan subsequently pardoned , Armenia announced it is " ready for war " .

#Text=The declaration is in-response to Safarov 's pardon and promotion , despite the Azeri officer having been given a life sentence — with a minimum jail term of 30 years , by Hungarian authorities in 2006 .
#Text=Safarov was found guilty of the 2004 murder of Armenian officer Gurgen Margaryan in Budapest , when both Safarov and Margaryan were attending a NATO Partnership for Peace programme .

#Text=Safarov killed Margaryan in his sleep with an axe ; the attack allegedly stemming from a desire to avenge Azeris killed during the Nagorno-Karabakh War and being mocked by Margaryan and another Armenian .
#Text=On his return home , Safarov was met with a hero 's welcome , given a pardon by president Ilham Aliyev , promoted to the rank of major , awarded eight-years of back-pay and given a house .
#Text=Armenia sees these acts , when it was expected that Safarov would serve out his prison term in Azerbaijan , as highly provocative .
#Text=Armenian President Serzh Sarkisian declared : " We do n't want a war , but if we have to , we will fight and win .

#Text=On Friday , The National Security Council of Armenia decided to break ties with Hungary during an emergency summit , describing the Hungarian actions as a  grave mistake " .

column1: #Text=In turn , the Azeri ambassador was summoned by Hungary on Monday regarding the breach of Azeri assurances that Safarov would serve out the remainder of his sentence in Azerbaijan .
